title: 112_s1827
content: The Trade Prosecutor Act of 2011 establishes a Trade Enforcement Division and Deputy United States Trade Representative for Trade Enforcement under the Trade Act of 1974. The Trade Enforcement Division is established within the Office of the United States Trade Representative, headed by a Deputy United States Trade Representative for Trade Enforcement appointed by the President with Senate approval. The Deputy United States Trade Representative for Trade Enforcement, appointed by the President with Senate approval, holds the rank of Ambassador and ensures compliance with trade agreements. They also assist in investigating and prosecuting disputes before the World Trade Organization. The Office of Trade Assistance for Small Business is established within the World Trade Organization and other trade agreements. It assists the United States Trade Representative in carrying out functions related to trade laws and barriers imposed by foreign governments. The Office of Trade Assistance for Small Business is established within the Division to provide technical and legal assistance to eligible small businesses for filing petitions under section 302. Eligible small businesses are defined as those lacking internal resources or financial ability for outside assistance. The Office of Trade Assistance for Small Business may consult with the Small Business Administration and other federal departments to determine eligibility of small businesses. A conforming amendment is made to the Trade Act of 1974. Establishment of Chief Manufacturing Negotiator and amendments to Deputy United States Trade Representative positions and Bipartisan Trade Promotion Authority Act of 2002. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to establish positions for Deputy United States Trade Representatives, Chief Agricultural Negotiator, and Chief Manufacturing Negotiator, all appointed by the President with Senate approval. Each official will hold office as per the Senate's rulemaking power. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to establish positions for Deputy United States Trade Representatives, Chief Agricultural Negotiator, and Chief Manufacturing Negotiator, all appointed by the President with Senate approval. The Chief Manufacturing Negotiator's main function is to conduct trade negotiations and enforce trade agreements related to US manufacturing products and services, advocating for US manufacturing interests. The Chief Manufacturing Negotiator is required to submit an annual report to the Senate and House committees on the actions taken in the preceding year. Section 5314 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include the Chief Manufacturing Negotiator. Technical amendments are made to the Trade Act of 1974 regarding pay rates.
